Project Number: 54111-001 
Transaction Technical Assistance Cluster (C-TRTA) 
April 2020 
 
 
 
Preparing and Implementing Gender-Inclusive 
Projects in Central and West Asia

Policy.

I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Analysis of Key Issues 
 
1.  Central and West Asia (CWA) countries have been experiencing growth in the past five 
years, albeit at varying levels.  However, within each country, the benefits are not equally shared 
by all. Despite their high educational attainment and participation in economic activities, working 
women generally receive 40% less than the salaries received by men.1 Women in Armenia, 
Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, and Kyrgyz Republic are 40% more likely to be unemployed than their 
male counterparts. Women often work in the agriculture and service sectors which pay lower 
wages compared to jobs in industry.  There are less women managers of medium and large 
enterprises or that hold management positions in government, especially in infrastructure sectors 
such as the energy, water, or the transport ministries. Job segregation and wage discrimination 
account for lower representation of women in higher-paying sectors and for the wage gap 
between sexes. A limited range of employment opportunities is available to women.2 The wage 
gap is associated with gender specialization in tertiary education and women’s burden of doing 
domestic and care work in their prime child-bearing years.  Decrease in social infrastructure 
provisions and social services restrict women’s participation in wage employment.3  
 
2.  While all CWA countries are committed to achieve their Sustainable Development Goals 
(SDGs), including SDG 5 on gender equality, they need support in mainstreaming gender equality 
goals especially in the infrastructure sectors, as well as in finance and public sector management.  
Investments by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in these areas have often tried to mainstream 
gender but have not always been successful. Of the 155 ongoing ADB projects in CWA, 37% are 
in the transport sector, 21% are in the energy sector, and 12% are in finance and public sector 
management – totaling 70% of projects in the most challenging sectors for gender mainstreaming. 
Sectors such as agriculture and natural resources, water supply and urban development, as well 
as the social sectors have been successful in incorporating gender in project design, as direct 
community interface presents gender mainstreaming opportunities. To address the challenges 
faced in mainstreaming gender in the infrastructure and finance and public management sectors, 
initiatives under  the regional technical assistance (TA) on Strengthening Gender-Inclusive 
Growth  in  Central  and  West  Asia 4 demonstrated  effective  gender  mainstreaming  (EGM) 
approaches in energy, transport, and finance and public sector management, and addressed 
some of the gender capacity building and policy support needs of executing and implementing 
agencies. The proposed transaction TA cluster will build on the lessons from the implementation 
of the regional TA, to inform the design of ensuing gender-responsive transaction TA subprojects. 
 
B.  Justification for Cluster Modality 
 
3.  The  transaction TA cluster will provide gender capacity building support and policy advice, 
as well as implement a gender component in each of the following ensuing sovereign projects:  (i) 
Batumi‒Sarpi  Bypass  Road  Project  (Georgia),  (ii)  Kyzylorda‒Zhezkazgan  Road  Project 
(Kazakhstan),  (iii)  Power  Sector  Development  Program  (Tajikistan),  (iv)  Bukhara‒Miskin‒
Urgench‒Khiva Railway Electrification Project (Uzbekistan), (v) Mortgage Market Development 
 
1  UNESCAP. 2018. Inequality in the era of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development: North and Central Asia. 
Kazakhstan. 
2  ILO. 1995. https://www.ilo.org/global/about-the-ilo/newsroom/news/WCMS_008091/lang--en/index.htm. Geneva. 
3  UNDP. 2016. https://www.undp.org/content/dam/rbec/docs/Gender%20inequalities%20in%20labour%20markets%20in%20Central%20Asia.pdf. 
Almaty. 
4  ADB. 2016. https://lnadbg1.adb.org/sec0094p.nsf/docbyno/48257fd500240ec148257fd500201cd8/$file/in86-16.pdf. 
Manila.

2 
Project (Krygyz Republic), (vi) SME Finance Project (Phase 1) (Turkmenistan), (vii) Regional 
Energy Transmission and Dispatch Enhancement Project (Uzbekistan), and (viii) Energy Sector 
Reforms and Financial Sustainability Program Subprogram 2 (Pakistan), and one ongoing project 
-- Improving Governance and Public Sector Efficiency Program Subprogram 2 (Azerbaijan). 
These sectors ─ transport, energy, and public sector management ─ are the most challenging for 
gender mainstreaming, as there is little community interface and project interventions could not 
demonstrate direct benefits to women. The transaction TA cluster will address these gender 
mainstreaming challenges, by supporting gender components of ensuing projects. These gender 
components are aligned with the gender focus area under Strategy 2030 on Operational Priority 
2 Gender Mainstreaming Approaches, and SDG 5 on Transformative Gender Agenda.5 Details 
of ensuing projects are in Appendix 1. Support from the transaction TA cluster is envisaged to 
improve  CWRD’s  gender  mainstreaming  performance  at-entry  and  at-exit,  and  help  the 
department meet its gender targets.6  
 
4.  The transaction TA cluster will also provide capacity building support to executing and 
implementing agencies of ongoing sovereign projects with gender mainstreaming. Most ongoing 
gender equity (GEN)/EGM projects have difficulties implementing their gender action plans due 
to the weak gender capacities of implementing agencies.  This may be attributed to the weak 
gender mainstreaming capacities of executing agencies (EAs)/implementing agencies (IAs), 
including the lack of gender integration in their policies, programs, projects, and services.  The 
transaction TA cluster will strengthen their gender capacities through provision of customized 
learning programs and provision of technical guidance and thereby improve the implementation 
and  monitoring  of  the  project  gender  action  plans  (GAPs).  The  ADB’s  Corporate  Results 
Framework  2019‒2024  includes  enhanced  gender  targets  and  indicators  that  need  to  be 
monitored and reported on.7 There are 103 ongoing projects with gender targets and indicators 
that need to be monitored. The transaction TA cluster will support the tracking of gender indicators 
and targets of ongoing projects. Due to its regional nature, the proposed transaction TA cluster is 
not included in a country operations business plan (COBP). 
 
5.  The advantage of a regional transaction TA cluster over the previous regional capacity 
development TA (footnote 2) is the ability of the transaction TA cluster to support the integration 
of gender components into ADB projects and programs that are difficult to engender, such as in 
energy, transport, and finance and public sector management.  At the same time, the transaction 
TA cluster allows for the continuing gender capacity building and policy development of sector 
ministries in connection with specific ADB projects, and is therefore a more effective modality than 
a knowledge and support TA. 
 
5  ADB.  2018.  https://www.adb.org/documents/strategy-2030-prosperous-inclusive-resilient-sustainable-asia-pacific. 
Manila. The five areas of focus under Strategy 2030 include: women’s economic empowerment, gender equality in 
human development, gender equality in decision-making and leadership, reduced time poverty of women, and 
women’s resilience to external shocks.  Operational Priority 2 identifies approaches to achieve Strategy 2030 gender 
targets. The SDG 5 Transformative Gender Agenda include: violence against women, unpaid care and domestic 
work, voice and leadership, sexual and reproductive rights, economic assets, ICT, legal/institutional reforms for 
norms change.  
6  ADB’s gender corporate target is that 55% of its projects should meet requirements for GEN or EGM categorization 
by 2030, as per ADB’s 4-tier gender classification system at-entry. Category 1 or gender equity (GEN) projects have 
direct gender benefits at the outcome level; category 2 or effective gender mainstreaming (EGM) projects have 
majority of their outputs incorporated with proactive gender design elements; category 3 or some gender elements 
(SGE) projects have only a sprinkling of proactive gender elements; and category 4 or no gender elements (NGE) 
projects do not have proactive gender elements. Only categories 1 (GEN) and 2 (EGM) contribute to meeting the 
55% gender target. Gender target at-exit is 80% of GEN/EGM projects should be rated “successful in GAP 
implementation”. 
7  ADB. 2019. https://www.adb.org/documents/adb-results-framework-2019-2024-policy-paper. Manila.

3 
 
C.  Outcome and Outputs 
 
6.  Overall outcome. The transaction TA cluster will have the following overall outcome:  
Gender mainstreaming in CWA operations expanded and improved.  Each transaction TA cluster 
subproject will deliver on the output to which it is aligned and this will be specified in each 
transaction TA subproject proposal. 
 
7.  Output  1:  Gender-inclusive  components  in  sovereign  projects  and  programs 
incorporated. Projects that do not easily lend themselves to gender mainstreaming require 
additional support to incorporate measures that will address gender gaps or promote gender 
inclusion.  Selected  components  of  upcoming  infrastructure  projects  will  model  women’s 
empowerment measures such as livelihood and entrepreneurship support, or financial literacy 
and investment trainings, or technical trainings to increase the number of women in science, 
technology, and engineering courses and improve women’s participation in infrastructure sectors, 
or  financial  inclusion  measures  for  unbanked  women  and  vulnerable  sectors.  Specifically, 
transactional TA subprojects 4, 5, 6, 8,10, 11, and 12 will provide capacity building support that 
will enable the ensuing projects to deliver their gender-related outputs. Subprojects 7 and 9 will 
provide capacity building support and policy advice on gender-responsive budgeting and inclusive 
financial inclusion to an ongoing8 and an ensuing project. Ensuing projects and programs with 
gender-inclusive  components  supported  by  the  transaction  TA  will  have  at  least  an  EGM 
categorization at-entry.  
 
8.   Output 2: DMC capacity for GAP implementation and monitoring of gender equality 
results enhanced. The quality of gender mainstreaming of ongoing sovereign projects with GAPs, 
and in sovereign programs with gender targets, will be improved. Ongoing projects and programs 
that have gender actions and targets in their design and monitoring frameworks (DMFs), or GAPs, 
or  policy matrices  need  to  be  carefully monitored to  ensure  quality  implementation.   Past 
experiences show that not all gender actions that have been implemented would result in the 
envisaged targets, and thus, do not help make the project “successful” at-exit. To systematize the 
monitoring of gender equality results, the development and maintenance of the Gender Database 
is included in this output. The database will track implementation of GAP activities and assess 
the  progress  towards achieving GAP  targets. Remedial  actions  can  be  taken  on  problem 
areas identified early enough and mitigate the risk of non-achievement of GAP targets. Close 
monitoring of GAP implementation also helps identify capacity building needs of EAs/IAs to better 
implement project GAPs. While project implementing units would usually have gender consultants 
to implement GAPs, there is still the need for ADB to monitor and provide technical gender 
guidance to ensure the quality achievement of GAP targets, ensure a ‘successful’ gender rating 
at-exit, and meet the Department’s overall gender targets at-exit. International and national 
gender consultants will be recruited in headquarters (HQ) and resident missions (RMs) to support 
the implementation, monitoring and reporting of gender actions of projects and programs in their 
specific countries of assignment.  (The list of ongoing projects with gender actions and targets 
that will be monitored is in Appendix 3.) Gender capacity building of partner sector agencies and 
national women’s ministries and agencies will be conducted at the national and subregional levels.  
 
D.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
 
9.  The transaction TA cluster is estimated to cost $3.0 million which will be financed on a 
grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 6 and TASF-other sources).  The 
 
8 ADB. 2019. https://www.adb.org/projects/documents/aze-51059-002-rrp. Manila.

4 
scope of the TA is expected to expand to cover additional activities consistent with the TA’s 
outputs. The list of indicative TA subprojects and their indicative budgets is provided in Table 2. 
Detailed cost estimates and financing arrangements will be presented in each TA subproject 
proposal submitted for approval. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will be the executing agency and will administer the transaction TA cluster. CWRD’s 
Portfolio,  Results,  Safeguards  and  Gender  Unit  (CWOD-PSG)  will  be  responsible  for 
implementing the transaction TA cluster, in close coordination with the sector divisions involved 
in the processing and implementation of specific subprojects. Each transaction TA subproject 
proposal will be submitted for approval to the CWRD Director General in accordance with the 
business process for transaction TA cluster processing. Subproject activities attached to loans 
will  start  only  after  loan  effectiveness.  CWOD-PSG  will  conduct  an  annual  review  of  the 
implementation progress of the transaction TA.

11.  Subprojects. The transaction TA cluster will be implemented through 12 subprojects as 
described in Appendix 2.9 Each subproject will be designed in accordance with the general output 
descriptions (paras. 7-8) as and when needed during the implementation period. Since some of 
the ensuing projects are complex, the risk categorization of this transaction TA cluster is complex.

12.  Consulting services. Individual consultants will be recruited through individual consultant 
selection method to provide 107 person months of international consulting inputs and 173 person-
months of national consulting inputs to implement subprojects 1, 2, 3, 7, and 9. A firm will also be 
recruited to implement each of the following subprojects – 2, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 11, and 12 using the 
consultants’ qualification selection method except for subproject 5 which will use the fixed budget 
selection method. The estimated cost and requisite fields of expertise are indicative and estimates 
will be finalized prior to approval of each TA subproject in consultation with the government. 
Detailed implementation arrangements and ADB procurement will be finalized prior to approval 
of  each  TA  subproject  in  consultation  with  the  governments  during  follow-up  missions. 
Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time).  
 
II.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $3,000,000 on a grant basis for 
Preparing and Implementing Gender-Inclusive Growth in Central and West Asia, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Implementation schedule  2021-2022 
Subproject 12   Building Capacities of Women in Renewable Energy  
Indicative outputs and activities   (i) Women trained in the installation, maintenance, and repair of 
solar technology; (ii) Women trained in establishing and managing 
energy enterprises; (iii) Women technical staff of energy agencies 
provided with leadership training 
Indicative implementation and  ADB (CWOD-PSG and CWEN) 
arrangements  
Implementation schedule  2021-2022 
CWA = Central and West Asia, CWEN = Energy Division, CWOD-PSG = Portfolio, Results, Safeguards and Gender 
Unit, CWPF = Public Management, Financial Sector, & Trade Division, CWRD = Central and West Asia Department, 
CWTC = Transport and Communications Division, DMC = developing member country, EGM = effective gender 
mainstreaming, GAP = gender action plan, GEN = gender equity, MOF = ministry of finance, PCR = project completion 
report, SME = small and medium enterprise, STEM = science, technology, engineering and mathematics, TVET = 
technical and vocational education and training. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
CWA  --  Central and West Asia 
CWRD  --  Central and West Asia Department 
CWOD  --  Central and West Asia Department Office of the Director General 
  EGM  –  effective gender mainstreaming 
  GAP  –  gender action plan 
GEN  --   gender equity theme 
PSG  --  Portfolio, Results, Safeguards, and Gender Unit 
SDG  --  Sustainable Development Goals 
TA  --  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE{S} 
 
           In this report, "$" refers to United States dollars  
 
 
 
Vice-President  Shixin Chen, Operations 1 
Director General  Werner E. Liepach, Central and West Asia Department (CWRD) 
Advisor and Head  Jesper K. Petersen, Portfolio, Results, Safeguards, and Gender Unit 
(CWOD-PSG), CWRD 
   
Team leader  Mary Alice G. Rosero, Social Development Specialist (Gender), CWOD-
PSG, CWRD 
Team members  Gladys P. Franco, Social Development Officer, CWOD-PSG, CWRD 
  Fritz T. Tuliao, Associate Project Analyst, CWOD-PSG, CWRD 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.
